The Respiratory System:
Smoking has a profound impact on the respiratory system, as the inhaled smoke irritates the airways and damages the lungs. The chemicals in cigarette smoke can cause inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to chronic bronchitis. Over time, this can result in a persistent cough, excessive mucus production, and difficulty breathing.

Moreover, smoking is a leading cause of lung cancer, responsible for approximately 85% of all cases. The carcinogens in tobacco smoke can cause mutations in the DNA of lung cells, leading to the uncontrolled growth of abnormal cells and the formation of tumors.

Cardiovascular Health:
Smoking also has a significant impact on cardiovascular health. The chemicals in cigarette smoke can damage the lining of blood vessels, leading to the buildup of fatty deposits (atherosclerosis) and narrowing of the arteries. This can increase the risk of heart attack, stroke, and peripheral artery disease.

Furthermore, smoking raises blood pressure and reduces the amount of oxygen that the blood can carry, which puts additional strain on the heart. Smokers are also more likely to develop blood clots, which can lead to heart attacks and strokes.
